Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial of Continuous Posterior Interscalene Block for Postoperative Analgesia

Intervention.evidence: randomised to receive either a continuous ropivacaine 0.2% perineural infusion or a normal saline infusion

Objective.evidence: This study investigates whether an ultrasound-guided continuous posterior interscalene block offers superior postoperative analgesia compared to a single-injection ropivacaine interscalene block after moderately painful shoulder surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was average pain on postoperative day (POD) 1, assessed on a 0–10 scale.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealment.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was maintained for patients, clinicians, and outcome assessors.

Number_Analysed.evidence: 30 were analysed per protocol (15 in each group)

Result_Outcome.evidence: Continuous ropivacaine infusion resulted in a significant reduction in average pain on POD 1 (median [10th–90th percentile]: 0.0 [0.0–5.0] vs. 3.0 [0.0–6.0]; P < 0.001).

Harms.evidence: No significant adverse events were observed.
